questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a newborn for potential metabolic disorders due to some concerning symptoms. Given the suspicion of phenylketonuria (PKU) among other metabolic conditions, the pediatrician considers the most effective screening method to identify such diseases in their early stages. Which screening test is considered the gold standard for detecting PKU and similar metabolic disorders in newborns?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Western blot: Incorrect, as it's primarily used for protein analysis and not typically for newborn metabolic screening.
  • • Option
  • • A. Western blot:
  • • Option B. Electrophoresis: Incorrect, while it can separate molecules based on size and charge, it's not as comprehensive or specific for metabolic disorders as tandem mass spectrometry.
  • • Option B. Electrophoresis:
  • • Option C. FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization): Incorrect, as FISH is mainly used for detecting chromosomal abnormalities and gene mapping, not for screening metabolic disorders like PKU.
  • • Option
  • • C. FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tandem Mass Spectrometry (MS/MS) is widely used in newborn screening programs for the detection of various metabolic disorders, including phenylketonuria (PKU). This method allows for the simultaneous screening of multiple disorders by analyzing patterns of specific metabolites in a small blood sample, usually obtained via heel prick in newborns. Its sensitivity and specificity make it an ideal choice for early detection.
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e :p 427
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e :p 427

questions.text: During a routine neonatal examination, a newborn girl is noted to have blue eyes, blond hair, and fair skin. A Guthrie test is performed, yielding positive results. Among the following statements related to this case, which one is NOT true?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to deficiency of enzyme Phenylalanine Hydroxylase

options.label: B
options.text: Mental retardation is a potential complication

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of a white patch of hair is due to a deficiency in tryptophan

options.label: D
options.text: Phenylacetate is found in the urine

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of a white patch of hair is due to a deficiency in tryptophan
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Presence of a white patch of hair is due to a deficiency in tryptophan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phenylketonuria results from phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, causing elevated phenylalanine levels and reduced tyrosine. The hypopigmentation seen in PKU patients is due to impaired melanin synthesis from reduced tyrosine availability—not from tryptophan deficiency. Early detection through newborn screening and prompt dietary management are essential to prevent the neurological sequelae of this inborn error of metabolism.
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p 304-306
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is evaluated for severe mental retardation and recurrent seizures. His blood ammonia levels are normal, and there is no acidosis. Non-ketotic hyperglycinemia is diagnosed based on an elevated CSF/blood glycine ratio. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Accumulation of neurotoxic intermediates are seen

questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Defect of glycine cleavage complex: True , this is the underlying defect in non-ketotic hyperglycinemia.
  • • Option
  • • A. Defect of glycine cleavage complex:
  • • True
  • • Option C. Also known as glycine encephalopathy: True , this is another name for non-ketotic hyperglycinemia.
  • • Option
  • • C. Also known as glycine encephalopathy:
  • • True
  • • Option D. Accumulation of neurotoxic intermediates are seen: True , the accumulation of glycine and related compounds can lead to neurotoxicity.
  • • Option
  • • D. Accumulation of neurotoxic intermediates are seen:
  • • True

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-ketotic hyperglycinemia , also known as glycine encephalopathy , is a rare genetic disorder caused by a defect in the glycine cleavage enzyme complex , leading to an accumulation of glycine and its neurotoxic intermediates . Unfortunately, effective management options are limited, and the disease often results in severe neurological deficits.
  • ➤ Non-ketotic hyperglycinemia
  • ➤ glycine encephalopathy
  • ➤ rare genetic disorder
  • ➤ defect in the glycine cleavage enzyme complex
  • ➤ accumulation of glycine
  • ➤ neurotoxic intermediates
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p 301, Vasudevan 9/ed: p 213.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Harper 30/e: p 301, Vasudevan 9/ed: p 213.

questions.text: A 24-year-old researcher is studying the antioxidant defense mechanisms in the human body and is particularly interested in the role of glutathione. While reviewing the literature, he encounters various functions and characteristics of glutathione but finds conflicting information regarding one of its roles. Based on your knowledge, which of the following statements about glutathione (GSH) is NOT true?

options.label: D
options.text: It is a cofactor of various enzymes

questions.correct_answer: B. It converts hemoglobin to methaemoglobin
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. True, as glutathione is composed of three amino acids: glutamate, cysteine, and glycine.
  • • Option
  • • A. True, as glutathione is composed of three amino acids:
  • • Option C. True , glutathione plays a significant role in the detoxification process by conjugating with various xenobiotics, aiding in their excretion from the body.
  • • Option C. True
  • • Option D. True , glutathione acts as a cofactor for glutathione peroxidase and other enzymes involved in the reduction of peroxides and maintenance of redox status within cells.
  • • Option D. True

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ G lutathione does not convert haemoglobin to methaemoglobin . Methaemoglobin formation occurs when the iron in hemoglobin is oxidized from the ferrous (Fe2+) to the ferric (Fe3+) state , which can happen through various mechanisms , but not directly due to glutathione. In fact, glutathione plays a role in reducing oxidative stress in cells and can help to protect against the oxidation of hemoglobin.

  • ➤ lutathione
  • ➤ not convert haemoglobin
  • ➤ methaemoglobin
  • ➤ Methaemoglobin formation
  • ➤ iron in hemoglobin
  • ➤ oxidized from the ferrous
  • ➤ ferric
  • ➤ state
  • ➤ various mechanisms
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p 272-273.
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p 272-273.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with a constellation of symptoms including flushing, a non-healing ulcer, diarrhea, and episodes of bronchospasm. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of 5-Hydroxyindoleacetic Acid (5-HIAA) in her blood. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A Glucagonoma: Is a rare tumour of pancreatic alpha cells , resulting in overproduction of glucagon . It is associated with necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss and diabetes mellitus.
  • • Option A Glucagonoma:
  • • rare tumour of pancreatic alpha cells
  • • overproduction of glucagon
  • • Option B. Gastrinoma: Is a gastrin secreting tumour of pancreas resulting in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome , where there is no feedback regulation of gastrin secretion causing very high level of gastric acid output along with high serum gastrin levels.
  • • Option B. Gastrinoma:
  • • gastrin secreting tumour
  • • pancreas
  • • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
  • • Option D. Insulinoma: Is an Insulin secreting tumours characterized by constant high production of insulin (C-peptide) and decreased blood glucose by the tumour cells.
  • • Option D. Insulinoma:
  • • Insulin secreting tumours
  • • constant high production of insulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carcinoid syndrome is characterized by a set of symptoms that include flushing, diarrhea, bronchospasm , and, in some cases, heart valve lesions . These symptoms are caused by the overproduction of serotonin by carcinoid tumors , most commonly originating in the gastrointestinal tract or lungs . Elevated levels of 5-Hydroxyindoleacetic Acid (5-HIAA), a metabolite of serotonin , in the urine or blood are a hallmark finding in carcinoid syndrome and support this diagnosis.
  • ➤ Carcinoid syndrome
  • ➤ set of symptoms
  • ➤ flushing, diarrhea, bronchospasm
  • ➤ heart valve lesions
  • ➤ overproduction of serotonin by carcinoid tumors
  • ➤ originating in the gastrointestinal tract or lungs
  • ➤ Elevated levels of 5-Hydroxyindoleacetic Acid
  • ➤ metabolite of serotonin
  • ➤ urine
  • ➤ blood
  • ➤ carcinoid syndrome
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: pg 557, DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 241-242
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: pg 557, DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 241-242

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with progressive involuntary movements in her right hand and visual difficulties noted over the past year. Blood work reveals elevated serum homocysteine with normal liver, renal, thyroid function tests, and electrolytes. She responds favorably to high-dose pyridoxine and a methionine-restricted diet, with a noted improvement in dystonic movements after three months. What condition is most likely affecting this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Hartnup’s disease: Due to defective absorption of aromatic amino acids from intestine as well as reabsorption from renal tubules →excretion of amino acids in urine.
  • • Option A. Hartnup’s disease:
  • • defective absorption of aromatic amino acids
  • • intestine
  • • reabsorption from renal tubules
  • • Option B. Cystinuria: Due to defect/deficiency of transporter system →patients cannot reabsorb cysteine into their bloodstream →accumulation of cystine in urine forms stones →leads to recurrent nephrolithiasis, obstruction, and finally renal failure.
  • • Option B. Cystinuria:
  • • defect/deficiency of transporter system
  • • bloodstream
  • • Option D. Cystathioninuria: Due to cystathionase deficiency , patient presents with mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia and endocrinopathies.
  • • Option D. Cystathioninuria:
  • • cystathionase deficiency
  • • mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia
  • • endocrinopathies.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Classical homocystinuria is often due to a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase, leading to elevated homocysteine levels . Treatment with high-dose pyridoxine (vitamin B6), a cofactor for the enzyme , can improve symptoms , and a methionine-restricted diet can help manage homocysteine levels . The improvement in dystonia with treatment supports this diagnosis.
  • ➤ Classical homocystinuria
  • ➤ deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase,
  • ➤ elevated homocysteine levels
  • ➤ high-dose pyridoxine
  • ➤ cofactor for the enzyme
  • ➤ improve symptoms
  • ➤ methionine-restricted diet
  • ➤ manage homocysteine levels
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 221.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 221.

questions.text: A young girl presenting in the OPD is notably tall and thin, with slender fingers and dislocated lenses. Further investigation reveals a deficiency in cystathionine beta synthase. To manage her condition, which amino acid should be supplemented?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Cysteine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Methionine: Incorrect, as supplementation could exacerbate the condition due to an already existing accumulation of homocysteine and methionine.
  • • Option
  • • B. Methionine:
  • • supplementation
  • • exacerbate the condition
  • • Option C. Serine: Incorrect, while serine is involved in one-carbon metabolism , it is not the primary amino acid affected in homocystinuria.
  • • Option
  • • C. Serine:
  • • one-carbon metabolism
  • • Option D. Tyrosine: Incorrect, as it is not directly involved in the metabolic pathway affected by cystathionine beta synthase deficiency.
  • • Option
  • • D. Tyrosine:
  • • not directly involved in the metabolic pathway

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystathionine beta synthase deficiency leads to classical homocystinuria , characterized by an inability to convert homocysteine to cystathionine , resulting in low levels of cysteine. Supplementing cysteine can help compensate for this deficiency and mitigate some of the disorder's metabolic effects.

questions.text: In a clinical seminar focused on oxidative stress and cellular antioxidants, a biochemistry professor discusses the biochemical properties that enable glutathione to act as a potent antioxidant. One medical student asks about the specific functional group in glutathione that is primarily responsible for its antioxidant activity. Which of the following is the correct answer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Hydroxyl: Incorrect, as the hydroxyl group is not the primary reactive group in glutathione involved in antioxidant activity.
  • • Option
  • • A. Hydroxyl:
  • • hydroxyl group
  • • not the primary reactive group
  • • Option C. Carboxyl: Incorrect, the carboxyl group is a common functional group in many biomolecules but not the key reactive group in glutathione for its antioxidant function.
  • • Option
  • • C. Carboxyl:
  • • carboxyl group
  • • common functional group
  • • biomolecules
  • • Option D. Guanidino: Incorrect, the guanidino group is found in arginine and is not involved in the antioxidant activity of glutathione.
  • • Option
  • • D. Guanidino:
  • • guanidino group
  • • found in arginine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sulfhydryl (-SH) group in glutathione is crucial for its role as an antioxidant. This group, found in the cysteine residue of glutathione, is highly reactive and can donate a hydrogen atom to neutralize free radicals , making it essential for reducing oxidative stress in cells.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with a history of myocardial infarctions and cerebrovascular accidents presents for a follow-up. His laboratory results indicate elevated homocysteine levels, which decrease following treatment with pharmacological doses of pyridoxamine. Considering the effect of pyridoxamine on homocysteine levels, which enzyme's activity is most likely enhanced by this treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Methionine synthase: Defect in methionine synthase will cause elevated homocysteine levels and it requires B 12 not B 6 .
  • • Option A. Methionine synthase:
  • • Defect
  • • methionine synthase
  • • elevated homocysteine levels
  • • B 12 not B 6 .
  • • Option B. N5, N10 methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase: A defect in this enzyme leads to elevated homocysteine but that enzyme has a requirement for NADH not vitamin B 6.
  • • Option B. N5, N10 methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase:
  • • defect in this enzyme
  • • elevated homocysteine
  • • Option D. Cystathionase: A defect in cystathionase (another B 6 requiring enzyme) will block the degradation of cystathionine → accumulation of the same but will not lead to significantly elevated homocysteine.
  • • Option D. Cystathionase:
  • • defect in cystathionase
  • • block the degradation of cystathionine
  • • accumulation of the same

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

Supplementation with pyridoxamine can enhance the activity of this enzyme , thereby reducing homocysteine levels in the blood .

questions.text: An 18-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with acute left flank pain extending to the pubic area. He has reddish-brown urine, and urinalysis reveals numerous red blood cells. Upon acidifying his urine with acetic acid, flat, hexagonal transparent crystals are observed. Abdominal X-ray shows radiopaque stones in both kidneys, and a passed stone is predominantly composed of cysteine. Based on this presentation, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment suggestion?

options.label: C
options.text: Utilize drugs that acidify the urine

questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Increasing ethanol content causes dehydration , which will increase the concentration of cysteine in the urine, leading to increased precipitation.
  • • Option A.
  • • Increasing ethanol
  • • dehydration
  • • Option C. Acidification also reduces the solubility of the cysteine stones, alkalinization of urine is usually recommended to increase cystine solubility.
  • • Option C.
  • • Acidification
  • • reduces the solubility
  • • cysteine stones, alkalinization
  • • urine
  • • Option D. Restricting glycine is not effective, as glycine is not a precursor of cysteine biosynthesis.
  • • Option D.
  • • Restricting glycine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystinuria - a genetic condition characterized by the excessive excretion of cystine in the urine, leading to stone formation. Cysteine is a product of methionine metabolism ; thus, restricting dietary methionine can help reduce cystine levels in the urine and prevent further stone formation.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with flank pain and difficulty urinating. Kidney stone analysis reveals calcium oxalate composition. His parents have a history of similar issues. The accumulation of oxalate in this patient suggests a metabolic challenge with which of the following substances?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Glyoxylate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation

  • • leucine metabolism

  • ➤ Calcium oxalate stone formation can be linked to a disorder in glyoxylate metabolism . When glyoxylate is not properly metabolized, it can be converted to oxalate , which then combines with calcium to form calcium oxalate stones. This condition, often inherited, leads to recurrent stone formation and can be indicative of a primary hyperoxaluria type.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department by his parents due to concerns about his behavioral problems. The biochemical hallmark is elevated homocysteine, which can be detected in blood and urine testing. Early diagnosis and treatment with vitamin B6 (pyridoxine), betaine, methionine restriction, and cysteine supplementation may prevent or minimize complications.

questions.text: A 28-year-old marathon runner visits a sports medicine clinic complaining of prolonged recovery times after long training sessions. questions.text: A woman of reproductive age with phenylketonuria (PKU) delivers her first child. The father has no family history of PKU. questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with intermittent involuntary tremors in his left hand, difficulty feeding himself, walking challenges, and poor gait coordination for the past month. questions.text: Following routine newborn screening, a child is found to have high levels of phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, indicative of phenylketonuria (PKU). Despite a phenylalanine-restricted diet, the child shows developmental delays. Which supplement might improve the child's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Tyrosine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Phenylketonuria (PKU) results from a deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH), the enzyme that converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. This deficiency leads to:
  • • Accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites (phenylpyruvate, phenylacetate, phenyllactate) Reduced tyrosine production, making tyrosine an essential amino acid in PKU patients
  • • Accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites (phenylpyruvate, phenylacetate, phenyllactate)
  • • Reduced tyrosine production, making tyrosine an essential amino acid in PKU patients
  • • In PKU treatment, dietary phenylalanine restriction is the primary approach to prevent neurotoxicity from excess phenylalanine. However, this restriction alone can lead to tyrosine deficiency, as tyrosine can no longer be synthesized from phenylalanine.
  • • Tyrosine is critical for:
  • • Production of neurotransmitters (dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine) Synthesis of thyroid hormones Melanin production
  • • Production of neurotransmitters (dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine)
  • • Synthesis of thyroid hormones
  • • Melanin production
  • • Tyrosine supplementation is therefore beneficial in PKU management as it:
  • • Addresses the conditionally essential status of tyrosine Supports neurotransmitter synthesis, potentially improving neurological function May reduce the risk of developmental delays associated with tyrosine deficiency
  • • Addresses the conditionally essential status of tyrosine
  • • Supports neurotransmitter synthesis, potentially improving neurological function
  • • May reduce the risk of developmental delays associated with tyrosine deficiency
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. 5-hydroxytryptophan : This is a precursor to serotonin in the tryptophan metabolism pathway. While serotonin levels might be indirectly affected in PKU due to competition between elevated phenylalanine and tryptophan for transport across the blood-brain barrier, supplementing with 5-hydroxytryptophan does not address the primary biochemical defect or the tyrosine deficiency in PKU.
  • • Option B. 5-hydroxytryptophan
  • • Option C. Melanin : This is an end product of tyrosine metabolism and not a supplement that would provide therapeutic benefit in PKU. The hypopigmentation sometimes seen in PKU patients is due to reduced tyrosine availability for melanin synthesis, but direct melanin supplementation would not address the metabolic or neurological issues.
  • • Option C. Melanin
  • • Option D. Phenylalanine : Supplementing with phenylalanine would be contraindicated in PKU as it would exacerbate the condition. PKU patients already have elevated phenylalanine levels due to impaired metabolism, and additional phenylalanine would increase toxic metabolite production and neurological damage.
  • • Option D. Phenylalanine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In phenylketonuria, phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency creates a metabolic block in converting phenylalanine to tyrosine. While dietary phenylalanine restriction is the mainstay of treatment, supplementation with tyrosine is important because it becomes an essential amino acid in this condition. Tyrosine supplementation supports neurotransmitter synthesis, and potentially improves developmental outcomes by addressing the "downstream" deficiency caused by the enzymatic block.
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 236.
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with developmental delay undergoes blood analysis, which reveals elevated levels of phenylalanine, phenyllactate, and phenylpyruvate. What is the hypothesized mechanism for developmental delay in this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Lack of tyrosine, now an essential amino acid

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibition of hydroxylating enzymes due to accumulation of phenylalanine

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of large, neutral amino acids in the brain.

questions.correct_answer: D. Lack of large, neutral amino acids in the brain.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Acidosis due to elevated phenyllactate: While acidosis can have deleterious effects on the body and can be a feature of organic acidemias , it is not the primary reason for developmental delays in conditions like phenylketonuria. Acidosis is more of an acute metabolic disturbance rather than a direct cause of chronic developmental issues.
  • • Option
  • • A. Acidosis due to elevated phenyllactate:
  • • acidosis
  • • deleterious effects
  • • body
  • • feature of organic acidemias
  • • Option B. Lack of tyrosine, now an essential amino acid: Tyrosine is a precursor for several neurotransmitters , and while its deficiency due to a block in conversion from phenylalanine can impact brain function , the developmental delay is more directly linked to the broader competition of phenylalanine with other LNAAs, rather than tyrosine deficiency alone.
  • • Option
  • • B. Lack of tyrosine, now an essential amino acid: Tyrosine
  • • precursor for several neurotransmitters
  • • deficiency
  • • block in conversion from phenylalanine
  • • impact brain function
  • • Option C. Inhibition of hydroxylating enzymes due to accumulation of phenylalanine: Phenylalanine can indeed inhibit certain enzymes , including hydroxylating enzymes , due to its elevated levels . This can have various metabolic effects, but the specific link to developmental delay is less direct compared to the competition of phenylalanine with other LNAAs for transport into the brain.
  • • Option
  • • C. Inhibition of hydroxylating enzymes due to accumulation of phenylalanine:
  • • Phenylalanine
  • • inhibit certain enzymes
  • • hydroxylating enzymes
  • • elevated levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Elevated levels of phenylalanine are known to interfere with the transport of other large , neutral amino acids (LNAAs) across the blood-brain barrier due to competitive inhibition . These LNAAs include tyrosine, tryptophan, and others that are precursors for key neurotransmitters essential for brain development and function. A deficiency in these neurotransmitters can result in developmental delays.
  • ➤ Elevated levels

  • ➤ interfere with the transport of other large
  • ➤ neutral amino acids
  • ➤ blood-brain barrier
  • ➤ competitive inhibition
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 236.

  • • earlier in the cycle
  • • supplementation
  • • not bypass the block
  • • Option C. Citrulline: Citrulline is upstream of the block and would not be effective in bypassing the enzyme deficiency.
  • • Option
  • • C. Citrulline:
  • • upstream of the block
  • • Option D. Argininosuccinate: This is the substrate that accumulates due to the enzyme deficiency and its supplementation would not be helpful.

  • • supplementation

Supplementation with arginine is beneficial as it provides an essential amino acid that is normally produced by the urea cycle and becomes essential in patients with this condition. This supplementation helps to continue the urea cycle, thus aiding in the detoxification of ammonia.

questions.text: A newborn becomes lethargic and drowsy on day 24 post-birth. Laboratory tests reveal hyperammonemia and orotic aciduria. Which compound is this infant unable to directly synthesize due to an enzymatic deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Carbamoyl phosphate: This compound is actually synthesized in excess in OTC deficiency because it cannot be properly utilized to form citrulline.
  • • Option
  • • A. Carbamoyl phosphate:
  • • compound
  • • synthesized in excess in OTC deficiency
  • • Option C. Argininosuccinate: The formation of argininosuccinate occurs after the synthesis of citrulline in the urea cycle , so while its production is also affected, the direct deficiency lies with the production of citrulline.
  • • Option
  • • C. Argininosuccinate:
  • • formation of argininosuccinate
  • • after the synthesis of citrulline
  • • urea cycle
  • • Option D. Arginine: Arginine is the final product of the urea cycle , and its synthesis is indeed affected by OTC deficiency, but the immediate block is at the formation of citrulline.
  • • Option
  • • D. Arginine:
  • • final product of the urea cycle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency , is one of the urea cycle disorders . OTC is responsible for the synthesis of citrulline from carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine . When OTC is deficient , carbamoyl phosphate cannot be converted to citrulline and instead is diverted to the pyrimidine synthesis pathway, leading to orotic aciduria.
  • ➤ Ornithine transcarbamylase
  • ➤ deficiency
  • ➤ urea cycle disorders
  • ➤ OTC
  • ➤ synthesis of citrulline
  • ➤ carbamoyl phosphate
  • ➤ ornithine
  • ➤ OTC is deficient
  • ➤ carbamoyl phosphate cannot
  • ➤ converted to citrulline
  • ➤ diverted to the pyrimidine synthesis pathway,

  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205.

  • • regulated step of pyrimidine biosynthesis

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with a diagnosed urea cycle disorder presents with recurrent episodes of hyperammonemia, especially after high-protein meals. Despite dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavenging medications, the child's ammonia levels remain intermittently elevated, leading to concerns about long-term neurological outcomes. The metabolic specialist considers augmenting the treatment regimen. Which combination of supplements could provide an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion and help manage the child's condition more effectively?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Arginine and glutamine: Glutamine is often elevated in UCDs as it binds with free ammonia ; however, supplementation with glutamine is not typically used for treatment because the body is already producing excess.
  • • Option
  • • A. Arginine and glutamine:
  • • Glutamine
  • • elevated in UCDs
  • • binds with free ammonia
  • • Option B. Lysine and glutamine: Lysine is not specifically involved in the urea cycle , and, as mentioned, glutamine is typically already elevated in UCDs.
  • • Option
  • • B. Lysine and glutamine:
  • • not
  • • involved in the urea cycle
  • • Option D. Lysine and benzoate: Lysine is not a supplement used in the management of UCDs , and while benzoate is used, it would not be paired with lysine for treatment.
  • • Option
  • • D. Lysine and benzoate:
  • • not
  • • supplement used in the management of UCDs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urea cycle disorders (UCDs) result in the body's inability to properly dispose of waste nitrogen from protein metabolism , leading to hyperammonemia. Arginine supplementation can be beneficial because it provides an essential amino acid that is often deficient in UCDs.
  • ➤ Urea cycle disorders
  • ➤ body's inability to properly dispose of waste nitrogen
  • ➤ protein metabolism
  • ➤ hyperammonemia.
  • ➤ Arginine supplementation
  • ➤ essential amino acid
  • ➤ Benzoate combines with glycine to form hippurate, which provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion . This combination can help reduce ammonia levels in the blood by providing substrates for other nitrogen disposal pathways.

  • ➤ alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205

questions.text: A 22-year-old male avid marathon runner presents to the clinic with fatigue and mild disorientation after long training sessions. Laboratory tests indicate slightly elevated ammonia levels. Given the patient's high level of physical activity, the physician considers the main route of ammonia transport from his skeletal muscles to the liver for detoxification. What is the primary form in which ammonia is transported in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Glutamine: While glutamine is a significant carrier of ammonia, particularly in the brain and other tissues , in the context of intense physical activity, alanine plays a more direct role in transporting ammonia from muscles due to its involvement in the alanine-glucose cycle.
  • • Option
  • • A. Glutamine:
  • • carrier of ammonia,
  • • brain and other tissues
  • • Option C. Both A and B: Although glutamine does play a role in ammonia transport , the primary form under conditions of intense physical activity, like marathon running, is alanine due to the rapid generation and need for detoxification of ammonia.
  • • Option
  • • C. Both A and B:
  • • glutamine
  • • role in ammonia transport

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During intense physical activity , alanine serves as the primary transporter of ammonia from skeletal muscle to the liver for detoxification , via the alanine-glucose cycle
  • ➤ intense physical activity
  • ➤ alanine
  • ➤ primary transporter of ammonia
  • ➤ skeletal muscle
  • ➤ liver for detoxification
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 203.
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 203.

questions.text: During a rural health camp screening in India, a 6-year-old boy is evaluated for developmental delay and unusual skeletal features. His parents report that he has a history of frequent eye and vision issues. A genetic enzymatic defect is suspected. Which condition is associated with a defect in the enzyme cystathionine synthase?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Hartnup’s disease: Due to defective absorption of aromatic amino acids from intestine as well as reabsorption from renal tubules due to mutation of SLC6A19 gene encodes the transporter protein (B0AT1) seen in Intestine and renal tubules →excretion of amino acids in urine. Due to deficiency of Tryptophan, Niacin is not produced and so, the presentation is similar to Pellagra.
  • • Option A. Hartnup’s disease:
  • • defective absorption of aromatic amino acids
  • • Option B. Cystinuria: Due to defect/deficiency of transporter system →patients cannot reabsorb cysteine into their bloodstream → accumulation of cystine in urine forms crystals and stones → leads to recurrent nephrolithiasis and obstruction of urine flow →c/f- severe, sudden flank pain, blood and WBC in urine, fever, and finally renal failure.
  • • Option B. Cystinuria:
  • • defect/deficiency of transporter system
  • • Option D. Cystathioninuria: Due to cystathionine deficiency , patient presents with mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia and endocrinopathies. Acquired Cystathioninuria might be due to pyridoxine deficiency, liver diseases and after thyroxine administration.
  • • Option D. Cystathioninuria:
  • • cystathionine deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystathionine synthase is an enzyme critical in the metabolism of methionine, converting homocysteine to cystathionine. A deficiency in this enzyme leads to homocystinuria, a disorder characterized by elevated levels of homocysteine, which can result in developmental delay, skeletal abnormalities, and ocular issues.
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 221.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 221.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby boy presents with a 6-day history of fever, cough, breathing difficulty, and Kussmaul respiration. On examination, he appears lethargic and dehydrated, and the mother reports his urine has a distinctive cheesy odor. Urine organic acid analysis indicates increased excretion of 3-hydroxybutyric acid and moderate levels of 3-hydroxy-isovaleric acid. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Isovaleric acidemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Hepatorenal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type I) is due to a deficiency of enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. C/F: mild mental retardation, Cabbage like odour in urine, hypoglycemia liver failure and finally death occurs
  • • Option B. Hepatorenal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type I)
  • • Option C. Phenylketonuria: defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase, gives mousy or musty odour.
  • • Option C. Phenylketonuria:
  • • Option D. Maple syrup urine disease: Deficiency of the branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase results in accumulation of branched chain ketoacids in blood, urine, and tissues. The urine has the maple syrup odour / burnt sugar smell with development of metabolic acidosis.
  • • Option D. Maple syrup urine disease:
  • • branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase
  • • maple syrup odour
  • • burnt sugar smell

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Isovaleric acidemia is characterized by the inability to properly break down the amino acid leucine, leading to the accumulation of isovaleric acid and related metabolites, including 3-hydroxybutyric acid and 3-hydroxy-isovaleric acid. The distinctive "sweaty feet" or cheesy odor of the urine is a classic clinical clue.
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p 309-312.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Harper 30/e: p 309-312.

questions.text: A 7-month-old baby, with a family history of a urea cycle disorder leading to the death of a sibling at 1 year of age, has been diagnosed with the same condition. What is the rationale for administering benzoic acid to individuals with a urea cycle enzyme defect?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides an alternative route for N 2 excretion through glycine conjugate, hippuric acid

options.label: B
options.text: It provides an alternative route for N 2 excretion through the N-acetyl glucuronic acid conjugate kynurenine

options.label: D
options.text: It neutralized NH 3 in both blood as well as urine

questions.correct_answer: A. It provides an alternative route for N 2 excretion through glycine conjugate, hippuric acid
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. It provides an alternative route for nitrogen (N2) excretion through the N-acetyl glucuronic acid conjugate kynurenine: This option is not accurate; kynurenine is a metabolite in the tryptophan degradation pathway and not directly related to the excretion of nitrogen in the context of urea cycle disorders.
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Option C. It inhibits adenylate deaminase: Adenylate deaminase is not directly relevant to the management of urea cycle disorders or the mechanism of action of benzoic acid in these conditions.
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Option D. It neutralizes ammonia (NH3) in both blood and urine: Benzoic acid does not neutralize ammonia directly; instead, it provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion by forming hippuric acid with glycine.
  • • Option
  • • D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In urea cycle disorders, benzoic acid provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion by forming hippuric acid with glycine, thus reducing ammonia levels in the body. This is crucial for managing hyperammonemia resulting from the body's impaired ability to convert ammonia to urea.
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: page 206.
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: page 206.

questions.text: The Nitrogen sources of UREA are ammonia and arginine. Choose the appropriate response.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ ammonia entering through carbamoyl phosphate
  • ➤ aspartate
  • ➤ conversion to argininosuccinate
  • ➤ Arginine,
  • ➤ not a primary nitrogen source
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 203.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 203.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl has been diagnosed with an inherited metabolic disorder. Her mother is cautioned that consuming "sugar-free" products containing aspartame could be harmful to her daughter's health. Based on this advice, which genetic disorder is the girl most likely to have?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Hyperornithinemia: This condition involves elevated levels of ornithine and is not directly related to aspartame consumption. Treatment- Low protein diet.
  • • Option A. Hyperornithinemia:
  • • Option B. Hyperuricemia: Characterized by elevated uric acid levels, it is not influenced by aspartame intake in the context described. Treatment- Reduce dietary intake of purine and restrict alcohol, uricosuric drugs (decrease the reabsorption of uric acid from kidney tubules) and reduce the urate production by allopurinol (analog of hypoxanthine).
  • • Option B. Hyperuricemia:
  • • Option D. Hypervalinemia: Involving elevated levels of valine, this condition is also not impacted by the consumption of aspartame. Treatment - Restrict valine in diet.
  • • Option D. Hypervalinemia:
  • • -

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inherited metabolic disorder characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the body.

  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p304-306

questions.explanation:

questions.text: A newborn present with milky white skin, white hair, and red-appearing eyes. Which enzyme defect is most commonly associated with this disorder?

Ans. C. Tyrosinase

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In managing a patient with Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), dietary restrictions are crucial. Among the following amino acids, which one does NOT need to be restricted in the diet for a patient with MSUD?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Valine: As a BCAA, valine needs to be restricted in the diet of MSUD patients.
  • • Option
  • • B. Valine:
  • • Option C. Leucine: Leucine accumulation is particularly toxic in MSUD, necessitating dietary restriction.
  • • Option
  • • C. Leucine:
  • • Option D. Isoleucine: Another BCAA that needs to be limited in the diet of patients with MSUD.
  • • Option
  • • D. Isoleucine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is characterized by a deficiency in the branched-chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase complex, leading to the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) and their corresponding keto acids in the blood. The primary amino acids affected are leucine, isoleucine, and valine.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male on tuberculosis treatment with isoniazid reports numbness and tingling in his fingers for the past 3 weeks. Laboratory tests reveal low pyridoxal phosphate levels and the presence of xanthurenic acid in urine. Which metabolic pathway's disturbance results in xanthurenic acid excretion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Phenylalanine: Disturbances in phenylalanine metabolism are associated with conditions like phenylketonuria (PKU), not characterized by xanthurenic acid excretion.
  • • Option
  • • A. Phenylalanine:
  • • Option C. Tyrosine: Tyrosine metabolism disturbances lead to different sets of conditions, such as albinism or tyrosinemia, but not to increased xanthurenic acid levels.
  • • Option
  • • C. Tyrosine:
  • • Option D. Histidine: Disturbances in histidine metabolism are associated with conditions like histidinemia, which do not result in xanthurenic acid excretion.
  • • Option
  • • D. Histidine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Xanthurenic acid excretion in urine is indicative of a disturbance in the tryptophan metabolism pathway. Isoniazid, an antitubercular drug, can cause vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency, as it competes with pyridoxal phosphate (the active form of vitamin B6) for binding sites. Vitamin B6 is a cofactor for several enzymes in the tryptophan metabolism pathway. Its deficiency can lead to an accumulation of intermediate metabolites like xanthurenic acid.
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 240.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 240.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male visits a dermatology clinic in India with white patches on the dorsal aspect of his left hand, progressively worsening over the past 3 months. Which enzyme is essential for melanin synthesis, possibly deficient in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Tyrosine Hydroxylase: Tyrosine is hydroxylated to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) by tyrosine hydroxylase, which requires BH4 and NADPH. Tyrosine hydroxylase is present in adrenal medulla and the DOPA thus generated is used for catecholamine synthesis.
  • • Option A. Tyrosine Hydroxylase:
  • • used for catecholamine synthesis.
  • • Option B Homogentisate Oxidase →Alkaptonuria (AR inheritance) →results in excretion of homogentisic acid in urine. C/F- blackening of urine on standing, Ochronosis and Black pigments over joint cavities to produce arthritis.
  • • Option B Homogentisate Oxidase
  • • C/F-
  • • Option C. Tyrosine Transaminase: Deficiency leads to Oculocutaneous Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type II), C/F - Mental retardation, keratosis of palmar surface, painful corneal lesions and photophobia with increased excretion of tyrosine and tyramine in urine. A diet low in protein is advised.
  • • Option C. Tyrosine Transaminase:
  • • C/F

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Melanin synthesis requires the enzyme tyrosinase, which catalyzes the oxidation of tyrosine to DOPA and DOPAquinone, key steps in the production of melanin. A deficiency or functional impairment in tyrosinase can lead to conditions like vitiligo or albinism, characterized by the loss of pigmentation in the skin.
  • ➤ Ref : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 239.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 239.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant with pale skin and blonde hair is presented to the pediatric outpatient department by her parents. The infant has two siblings with complete albinism, while both parents are phenotypically normal. Based on this family history and the clinical presentation, which statement is correct regarding albinism?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased tyrosinase activity will be observed in melanocytes

options.label: C
options.text: Mental retardation is the main characteristic feature in albinism

options.label: D
options.text: Skin has high pigmentation in albinism

questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Increased tyrosinase activity: Incorrect. Albinism is usually associated with decreased or absent activity of tyrosinase in melanocytes, not increased activity.
  • • Option A. Increased tyrosinase activity:
  • • Option C. Mental retardation: Incorrect. Albinism does not inherently affect cognitive function; mental retardation is not a characteristic feature of albinism.
  • • Option
  • • C. Mental retardation:
  • • Option D. Skin has high pigmentation: Incorrect. Albinism is defined by reduced or absent pigmentation in the skin.
  • • Option
  • • D. Skin has high pigmentation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Albinism is characterized by a deficiency or absence of melanin pigmentation and can often result in photophobia due to the lack of melanin in the iris and retinal pigment epithelium. This causes increased light penetration into the eye, leading to discomfort in bright environments.
  • ➤ Ref : Vasudevan 9/ed: p 238.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Vasudevan 9/ed: p 238.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman in India presents with fever, left flank pain radiating to the leg, and acute urinary retention. She has a similar past episode six months ago. On examination, she's tender in the abdominal region and appears anemic. Urinalysis reveals RBCs, pus cells, WBC casts, hexagonal crystals, and amino acids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Cystinosis: This is a lysosomal storage disorder with accumulation of excess cystine crystals in eyes and kidneys. Due to mutation in the gene CTNS, which codes for the protein cystinosin, the lysosomal cystine transporter. Symptoms: excessive urination, poor growth, photophobia and renal failure by age 6.
  • • Option A. Cystinosis:
  • • Option C. Renal Fanconi syndrome: Caused by Cystinosis with loss of large amounts of salt and other minerals in urine. It is an example of RTA Type 2, characterized by increased urinary excretion of glucose, amino acids, bicarbonate, phosphate and salt wasting.
  • • Option C. Renal Fanconi syndrome:
  • • Option D. Cystathioninuria: Due to cystathionase deficiency, presents with mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia and endocrinopathies. Acquired Cystathioninuria might be due to pyridoxine deficiency, liver diseases and after thyroxine administration.
  • • Option D. Cystathioninuria:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of characteristic hexagonal crystals in the urine along with RBCs, pus cells, and WBC casts suggests a stone-forming condition. Cystinuria is a genetic disorder characterized by defective renal tubular reabsorption of certain amino acids including cystine, leading to the formation of cystine stones, which can manifest with urinary retention and flank pain due to obstruction.
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p 301-302.

questions.text: At a Health fair, a nutritionist sets up an interactive booth focusing on amino acids and their derivatives, highlighting their roles in nutrition and health. One of the informational posters prompts visitors to match lesser-known names of amino acid derivatives with their more common terms. A visitor, intrigued by the challenge, points to "N-Methyl Glycine" on the poster. She asks the nutritionist for its commonly known name. How should the nutritionist respond?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Ergothioneine: This is a derivative of histidine, not related to N-Methyl Glycine.
  • • Option
  • • A. Ergothioneine:
  • • Option C. Carnosine: This dipeptide consists of beta-alanine and histidine, differing significantly from N-Methyl Glycine.
  • • Option
  • • C. Carnosine:
  • • Option D. Betaine: Derived from choline, betaine serves as a methyl donor in various biochemical processes but is not synonymous with N-Methyl Glycine.

  • • D. Betaine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ N-Methyl Glycine is more commonly known as sarcosine. It is a derivative of glycine, where a methyl group is added to the amino acids nitrogen atom. Sarcosine plays various roles in biological systems, including in metabolism and nutrition.
  • ➤ Ref : Harper 30/e: p 284.
